text: (upbeat music)
- I am Taimur Rashid,

head of generative AI
innovation delivery at AWS.

Join me as I talk to
leaders and innovators

across Amazon who are
using AWS generative AI

to create hyper-personalized
experiences for customers,
streamline operations,
improve productivity, and so much more.
Learn more inside gen AI at Amazon.

I'm really excited today,
I have a guest, Jean-Luc.
Welcome Jean.
- Thank you, happy to be here.

- Tell us a little about yourself
and what you do at Amazon.
- Well, I've been at Amazon for a while,
14 plus years now.
Started a long time ago back in Europe

and then moved over to the
advertising team in 2012.
- [Taimur] Okay.
- So today I oversee mainly our creative

building capabilities and
our advertising formats
across a number of different
advertising solutions that we offer.
- Okay, that sounds great.
You know, we've had a tradition at Amazon
to use AI and machine learning
in many parts of our business.
And as I understand,
Amazon Ads has been using AI quite
a bit throughout the years.
Can you tell us a little bit about that?
- You know, it's funny because AI
is a really loaded term in my opinion,

and I think a lot of people
share that sentiment.

We've been using machine
learning, deep learning,

all of those type of
technologies for a long time.
I remember the early days of advertising

or whether it's for sponsor
products or sponsor brands

or other type of advertising
solutions that some
of our customers might be familiar with,
AI has been at the core of a lot
of those innovations and solutions.
- Well, that's really great.

How do you use generative
AI within your team?

- So what's interesting
about this question
is we didn't think of it in terms
of how can we use generative AI,
but rather starting from an actual
customer problems that we were facing.
A lot of our advertisers were running
into a very concrete and real challenge.
They did not have advertising created,

they didn't have images,
they didn't have videos
that would allow them to go create

the advertising campaigns
that they wanted to.
So that was 75% of them were telling us,
"I just can't do it.
It's too expensive, it's too difficult.
I don't have the skillset or expertise."
And so that's when we saw that problem

and then we saw the
rise of the capabilities
of generative AI, we saw a match,
we saw that there were capabilities
that we can start building

that would allow us to
shadow those barriers

for them to be able to access
an advertising solution
that they couldn't before.
So last October, a year ago,
we released image generator,
which is a generative AI capability

and it's a very exciting
and very simple one.

You give us a product
detail page on Amazon,

something that you sell, and
when you click of a button,
we can generate four stunning images
that you can use in an ad campaign.

And if you don't like them,
you can just regenerate.

We'll generate four
more and it's all free.
All you gotta do is then attach them
to an ad campaign and run.

And we've had tens of
thousands of advertisers
using that capability and are using it
in live campaigns today.
And this last unBoxed,

which is the Amazon
advertising conference,

we announced video
generator, which allowed us

to actually create videos
in the same context.

You give us a product and we
can create a video for that.
So we're really excited about the type
of capabilities generative AI offers

that make their life of
customers way simpler.

- Yeah, I'm so glad you
talked about, you know,

it's not about how do
you use generative AI,

it's really going back
to the use cases, right?
- Yeah.
- And for the most part, understanding

what persona are you really
empowering with generative AI.

We talked to a bunch of
customers from that perspective,

which is taking a persona
view by adding generative AI,

how are you giving that
persona superpowers,

number one, and how are
you actually helping them

be more productive in
the work that they do?
I wanted to switch gears a little bit

and talk a little bit about
the technology underneath.
So AWS has a variety of different services

to help builders build
these gen AI applications.

Can you talk a little
bit about what services
you use and how you use them?

- We're heavily leaning
into AWS services for sure,
and we've, over the years, constructed
a number of different solutions
around AWS solutions, in general.
For this one specifically, it's really,
or I guess for the generative AI ones

in that we've been so far,
it's been a collection
of different services.

We used Amazon SageMaker,
we've used some versions
of Bedrock, Amazon Bedrock.

We've used some versions of
Amazon, AWS Titan as well.

So we're iterating on
all of those structures

and what we found to
be incredibly exciting
is the flexibility that this offers.
We can go test something really quickly.
If that doesn't flow and doesn't work,

we can quickly revert back
or add some new services.
And it allowed our engineering
and science team to move incredibly fast.

That's actually the
topic of one of our talk
at AWS re:Invent coming up.

So if you're not, if
you're gonna be in town...
- I'll definitely be there.

I'll definitely make
sure that I attend it,
'cause I'd love to learn more about it.
No, that's great.

You're using different
parts of the platform
to be able to build these applications.
As you think about the metrics,
like the metrics that you measure to see
how effective the investment in gen AI is,

has the team started to
think about, you know,

what those metrics are,
what kind of outcomes

you're looking to drive,
whether it's efficiency gains

or just reducing cycle
time with, you know,
ad campaign creation?
- Well, we've thought specifically
around customer experience metrics
and how can gen AI help with those.

And so for instance, we
are thinking in terms
of the time it takes to create a campaign,

the time it takes to
generate those assets,
the quality of those assets,
how those assets end up performing,

specifically in the
context of ad campaigns.

So we're thinking through all
of those different aspects.

Still very early days,
but I can say for sure

that the faster we can
generate an asset, the better.
- Yeah, absolutely.
You know, building these gen AI apps,
it's on the bleeding edge of a lot

of these application capabilities
that are being introduced.
But a lot of the work also goes back
to foundational work, right?
So how the data platform is set up,

what sorts of security and
guardrailing mechanisms
you build around it, right?

What sort of considerations
went into that,
either as you were pursuing these
or prior to pursuing them?

- Well, there's a number
of, I wanna say learnings
on that space for us for sure.

And what was interesting
is as we were seeing
a rapid increase in the capabilities,
or at least the desire for us
to build those capabilities,

we realized that having
stringent guardrails

around privacy security
were absolutely critical.

And I wanna say that in a
the most honest context,

this isn't just a PR
or a legal requirement.

We saw it as a core customer
experience requirement.

We saw it as a way for
us to understand better
the prompts and refine the prompts.

We saw it as a way for
us to evaluate the models
and test the outputs of the models.

We saw it as a way for
understanding better
how the customers actually intended

to use the tools and what
they're trying to do.

So it really built a lot of
new knowledge for us around

that space because they
have the rapid iteration
and the almost conversational aspect

of the interactions customers
will have with those models.
- Now I'm glad you really referenced that

because there are a lot
of lessons to be learned

as people create these
bleeding edge applications,

right, and introduce
them into the core ops.
As you kind of look at the path forward
with how to expand on the great work
that you're doing already,

what are some areas you're
thinking about as a team
as far as functionality or capabilities

that you wanna add, you
know, in the future?
- My, there's so much (laughs)
- [Taimur] Yeah.

- Whether it's, you know, ideas
coming from our engineers,
our scientists or customers,

we have quite a collection
of ideas in play.

We just, as I mentioned,
rolled out video generator

and we're gonna be scaling
it as fast as we can.
We have new ideas like starting an image
and then making animate that image.
And so we call that live image.

And so how do we take that
and use it in a context
of an advertising experience.

We have other ideas, like
you already have a video
that's on your product detail page
that's maybe a 10 minute unboxing video,
or can we have an AI watch that video

and then provide a summary
that we can then use
in the context of an ad if you want to.

And so we're actually seeing
generative AI as a way

to start blending those
different types of media,
whether it's image and video,

and try to create an experience
that would be beneficial

to the shoppers that will
interact with this ad.

And that will create
performance by the advertisers.

And so all those different
ideas are coming together.
And generative AI has been an enabler

for both innovation and
invention within the team

and within our interactions
with customers.

- You know, it's amazing
how this technology

is just opening so many
doors for creativity
and, you know, just kind of reinventing

and reimagining the
experience that many people
go through and building applications,
but then also the experience
that customers get on the other end.
So it's pretty fascinating.

Well, I do wanna thank you
for the time that you share,

you know, and the insights
that you shared with us.

I definitely look forward to
attending your re:Invent talk

here in Las Vegas in
just about a month or so.
Thanks, once again.
- Thanks for your time.
- Alright, thank you.
(upbeat music)
